But those votes won’t be counted until Jan. 6th! Three days after the new Congress is sworn in the electoral ballots will be officially opened and counted in a joint session of the House and Senate and THEN the winner will be official.

With very rare exceptions electors cast their votes for president to match the winner of the popular vote determined in their state. This year the electors will cast their votes on Dec. 14th and deliver them to the president of the Senate by Dec. 23rd.

States have until Dec. 8th known as the “Safe Harbor” deadline to resolve any electoral contests. By Dec. 14th each governor must prepare a “Certificate of Ascertainment” or a list of electors and the number of popular votes received by each party.

Many states allow mail-in ballots to be processed weeks or days in advance but in 6 states including the battlegrounds of WI and PA election workers must wait until Election Day. With lots of mail-in ballots this year counting them could take longer than we are used to.

Antibody testing for #COVID19 could eventually be a critical tool for reopening the economy. But the tests currently on the market have not been validated by the #FDA. Many have been fraudulently marketed and others simply do not work. https://t.co/IZZhC67UAn
As the parent of a toddler I couldn't be more excited about today's CNN/Sesame Street Town Hall happening NOW! https://t.co/AKWzJXu11v

Not only do the tests need to work doctors and patients need to know how to use them effectively to fight COVID-19.  The CDC must put out guidance ASAP about if and when antibody tests should be used and what to do with the results. Not doing so will risk more lives.

There’s still time to fix this. Commissioner Hahn and the FDA can require test-makers to submit data and tests to review crack down on the bad actors get junk tests off the market and ensure only effective tests are used to fight COVID-19. The FDA needs to act now.

Hahn said FDA provided “flexibility” in the marketing of serological tests but that’s just a euphemism for “laissez-faire.” “Flexibility” has allowed junk tests to flood the markets sacrificing quality and reliability for the sake of free market access.

The National Cancer Institute voluntary review program is designed for failure because there is no plan for FDA to review tests it doesn’t receive. Junk test-makers won’t voluntarily give their tests to the government to reveal they don't work; they'll just keep selling them.

Commissioner Hahn has characterized the antibody tests the FDA has failed to review as “self-validated.” Given the presence of so many faulty tests on the market it might be more fitting to describe them as “unregulated” and that is a serious problem.

The FDA isn’t even asking serological test-makers for validation data or documents to support their claims: it's just accepting those claims at face value and allowing companies to sell their products. Because of this failed policy there are bogus COVID-19 tests on the market.

Commissioner Hahn didn’t deny my subcommittee’s staff findings that the FDA hasn’t been validating the effectiveness of serological tests for COVID-19; it’s just taking the word of the test-makers that they validated their test and are following FDA rules. https://t.co/MtoEaUweYK

I'm disappointed by #FDA Commissioner Hahn's response to a question about my subcommittee's investigation into the major flaws in the Administration's handling of coronavirus serology testing and the fact that the FDA doesn't know whether the tests currently on the market work. https://t.co/PhuuJluRNr

Serological testing for #COVID19 could eventually be a critical tool because these blood tests could potentially provide an efficient way to detect who's had the disease. But #FDA is unable to validate the accuracy of the tests currently on the market. https://t.co/MtoEaUweYK
